body: This may have been fixed by a recent PR: https://github.com/eclipse/rdf4j/pull/670

@ansell actually it isn't, because I forgot to revert the change to AbstractBindingSet - I only reverted the Literal hashcode change. 

@avataar do you have a simple test case that demonstrates the problem? Would be good to add a unit test to check for future regression.

I also note that, analogous to the (now reverted) change to literal, this change breaks our own API spec. `BindingSet.hashCode` has the following javadoc: /** * The hash code of a binding is defined as the bit-wise XOR of the hash codes of its bindings: * * 
	 * int hashCode = 0;
	 *
	 * for (Binding binding : this) {
	 * 	hashCode ˆ= binding.getName().hashCode() ˆ binding.getValue().hashCode();
	 * }
	 *
* * Note: the calculated hash code intentionally does not depend on the order in which the bindings are * iterated over. * * @return A hash code for the BindingSet. */ Not too happy with showing actual code in the javadoc tbh, but it's pretty clear that the changed impl violates this.
Having a look at adding regression tests for the various BindingSet impls now.

In my view, it isn't necessary in the long term to define the hashcode algorithm, as it encourages users to expect the result to be constant which doesn't allow for improvements in future to better distribute the hashcodes. It also encourages them to erroneously think that they can use hashcode as an alternative to equals for equality. Ie, ```object1.hashcode == object2.hashcode``` has no significance at all if ```!object1.equals(object2)```.

I am fine with removing the algorithm from the API javadoc in a minor version release.

issue.title: Fix #676: revert changes to hashcode of AbstractBindingSet

repository.name: rdf4j
repository.description: Eclipse RDF4J: scalable RDF for Java

issue.body:
This PR addresses GitHub issue: #676 .

Briefly describe the changes proposed in this PR:

* reverted changed hashcode impl back to be API-conformant 
* add regression tests for all BindingSet implementations

issue.title: Remove implementation details from Javadoc for Literal.hashCode and BindingSet.hashCode

repository.name: rdf4j
repository.description: Eclipse RDF4J: scalable RDF for Java

issue.body: Followup of #676 and #668 . The Javadoc in the interfaces for Literal and BindingSet contains too much implementation detail. This should be removed as it can falsely lead users to assume the implementation will never change.

body: Thanks @avataar . Have a look at the PR, which contains tests and a fix.
